transcripts.text: In the studio, the man who, wow, really got the country into yet more battles.  Forget Brexit.  No, the divide over what Lawrence Fox had to say on Question Time last Thursday appears to have completely divided the nation.  He was the actor and musician who basically said, no, the country isn't racist against Meghan Markle.  And no, we shouldn't just elect a Labour leader because she's a woman.  And he's also said he doesn't like dating women under the age of 34 because they're a bit too woke.  Delighted to welcome Lawrence Fox to the studio.  Oh, you're in a lot of trouble, aren't you?
Oh, I am.  What was I thinking?

The woke Witchfinder generals are very much out for you.  Now, you got a lot of support from the Question Time audience when you talked about how, you know, we're a nice country.  We're not racist.  We've been talking about the royals all morning as we do every day at the moment.  Why do you think some people are claiming that Meghan has been a victim of racism in this country and that we're just a nasty, horrible country and the media's nasty and racist and she couldn't possibly stay here and has been driven away?
I think it's how they fulfil their argument, isn't it?  You can't be a wokist without blaming everybody for being racist and you have to be very intersectional and victim-y.
And you have to think that the world's a bad place?
Yeah, and it's just not hopeful.  What world do you want to live in?  A world where everyone's racist?  Or do you want to live in a world where we're trying to come together?
Do you think this country is racist?
I think there's racism everywhere, but I don't think we're a systemically racist country.  I don't see a lot of racism, but then again, I am a straight white male.

And this came up again.  You actually accused a woman of colour of being racist herself because she talked about your white privilege.  Again, this is the intersectionality, this sort of diversity issue and identity issues.  You're a white male.  I mean, you're privileged.  You're from a posh family.  You're in a career where you've got lots of links.  You're not allowed to speak about anything, are you?  I mean, straight, white, middle class or posh.  I mean, I don't think you're allowed to have an opinion on anything, are you?

I'm at the bottom of the intersectional ladder, that's for sure.  But, yeah, I think she was being racist at the end of the day.  I didn't raise colour at all or anything.  She went, you're a straight white male, and technically that's racist.  If I'd described her in her...
You can't say that, you're black.

I was really surprised that it created such a drama, but I think it created such a drama because actually the British are very patient about... And I think we're tired of being told that we're racist by the people that we pay money for and support and generally applaud.  So it just hurts that little bit extra when you're called a racist on top of it.

And we had that, of course, over the whole Brexit debate.  So we've had that over a lot of issues lately.  Do you think this is the start of the fight back?  There's a lot of talk about Brexit being delivered, trying to move on from those divisions, about Boris Johnson's victory over Jeremy Corbyn.  Now, there'll be lots of reasons why that happened, but part of it surely must be a fight back against sort of obsession with identity politics, obsession with those sort of things.

It's so dangerous, identity politics.  There's nothing good about it.  It's, you know, even Shammi Chakrabarti saying to me, you know, shouldn't it not be a woman?  Isn't that very disparaging to women to say, well, we must put a woman ahead because she's not as good as a man in some way, so let's, you know, gee her up.  That's extremely patronising to women.
Well, Chess Phillips in an interview on Sky News yesterday...
Oh, my goodness, like...

She was asked, you know, Labour's never had a leader who's a woman.  All the other political parties have somehow managed it without an all-women shortlist.  But she was asked whether or not a man should stand aside.  She said sometimes if you really believe in it, then a man should, you know, hand the mic over effectively.

I think it's a great idea if you've got two people that are just there and they're the same level of quality candidate and the support is 50-50.  I think why not give the woman a chance ahead of the man?  because she tends to get less of a chance in this world.  but let's not assume that that we live in a world where women are discriminated against.  you're everybody is discriminated against by everybody.  what sort of society do we want to live in?  i want to live in one where we come together not one that divides us or just and it's old-fashioned idea meritocracy.  why not?  you know it's always good otherwise you get some.  you wouldn't want to be on a plane by with a pilot saying you know i got this job for diversity reasons.  would you?

Yes, rather than... I mean, for me, the whole... Raised in a very sort of liberal family, what would count as... Sort of the values I was raised with, which was that you don't judge people by their skin colour, their sexuality, their gender.  You judge people on merit.  Martin Luther King, you know, the character...
From some of the Twitter feed, I try and avoid it, but a lot of people say, we've moved on from Martin Luther King.  I'm like, yeah, good plan.  Yeah.  Let's move on from Martin Luther King.

He has some quite sensible things to say.  But when you say things like, I don't see colour now and I don't judge people on that and it's irrelevant, that is now a position that people accuse you of being a fascist, not you, but people accuse you of being fascist and pretending they're colourblind and that in itself is a form of racism and white privilege, as opposed to what, certainly in my upbringing, was what was called a liberal modern
value.  Yeah.  Well, we have to remember that what they're accusing you of is what they are, and that's why I stand up against them, because they are everything they accuse you of.
You think the people who are going around shouting racist at everybody...
The wokest, I think, are fundamentally a racist bunch.
Why do you think they are?
Because they are racist.
They see colour everywhere.
They see colour everywhere.
It's the only thing they see.
Yeah, and identity politics is extremely racist as well.

Eventually, it also does atomise society, isn't it?  So much about society, the melting pot, this idea was that we'd all just, you know, you just judge people on their merits, as opposed to everybody coming from their little corner.  So I'm a white, middle-class, straight woman.  You know, someone else might be a black, lesbian man, as opposed to just being individual personalities.

Right.  I think it's about silencing opinion.  I mean, I've certainly noticed it with me because I wasn't expecting it to kick off.  But it's like, you're not allowed an opinion, mate.  You're white.  And it's like, oh, sorry, I've got one and I'm going to keep shoveling it down your neck.  Sorry.

Now, you've been, some would say, a mischief maker for many years, ever since you were expelled from school and the like.  But you were criticised by none other than, I mean, of course, it was only a matter of time, singer Lily Allen.  That hurt.  I bet that really hurt.  What a surprise, expressed her view on Twitter, saying she was sick to death of lovies like Lawrence Fox, going on TV and forcing their opinions on everybody else when they'll never have to deal with what normal people have to deal with in his gated community.  Stick to acting, mate, instead of ranting about things you don't know anything about.  I mean, pot meet kettle, kettle meet pot.

I love the fact that you can go... I mean, she's had a pretty privileged, oh dear, upbringing, but no, she speaks for the common man, doesn't she?  And my gated community, we need to get some gates for it.  Because, yeah, it's not gated.
You've also talked about how you actually broke up with a girlfriend for being too woke, and you now have some rules about dating.  Tell us about those.

I don't think that... Anybody, man or woman, is going to be a great partner if they see themselves as the victim in a relationship before it's even started and that they're the victim of some tyrannical patriarchal oppression.  I think it's like, OK, bore off.  I mean, I just have no interest in it.  You need to be with somebody who's lived a real life, suffered hard and stood back on their feet again.  That's what excites me in someone, not someone going, it's awful.

And is that one of the things, I mean, the victimhood?  We've now got a situation where women are automatically victims, ethnic minorities victims, anyone who is not, again, a straight white male is a victim.
Unless you're in an Asian, unless you're in an American university and you're Asian, and then you really are actually a victim.

Yeah, it's quite bizarre, isn't it?  We seem to talk about these issues far, far more than certainly we did when I was a child.  But is that because, I mean, some people might argue that's a good thing that people are discussing these things.  Do you think it's a good thing?
Does it look like it's a good thing?
Is it working out?
It's not doing anything but dividing us, that I see.  I think we've got to think, we've got to judge someone on the content of their character, not the colour of their skin.  It doesn't help anybody.
Do you find you're judged on that?  Obviously, you're part of an acting dynasty.  You've got very famous parents, famous siblings.

It's fair enough.  I've been taking it in the neck for being a posh boy actor who's only got a gig because my dad's an actor since the beginning of my career.  And I'm like, fair enough.  You can have a pop at me.
I still pay my bills?

I still pay my bills and my tax bill.  You know, it's like, I don't mind someone taking a pop at me.  In actual fact, as someone who likes freedom of speech, continue to take a pop at me.  I just lose interest when I get, someone says, I want to unload both barrels of a shotgun into your face.

Yes, that perhaps might be going a little bit too far.  Do you think that, I mean, again, from the reaction you had on Question Time, and I know you said 100,000 extra Twitter followers, you've had a lot, I mean, some of those, just to warn you, they're going to be people who are just following you just to take offence at everything you say.  I know this is going to shock you.  Really?  But an awful lot of people are also speaking out.  When I tweeted out you were going to be on my show, just wave of joy from people saying, yes, thank God.  Tell them, you know, a lot of ladies expressing a lot of interest, by the way.  They say they're over 30 and they're not woke and they're willing to, I'll hand out numbers.
My girlfriend will be furious.

Oh, she will.  In that case, I won't hand out numbers.  But an awful lot of people just say, someone's saying what we're all thinking.  And this is the thing.  We had that, you know, I think with Boris Johnson to a certain extent and Nigel Farage and some of the other people who've been speaking out in the last few months.  I think it's got a bit more brave.  Douglas Murray and people like that.  And saying things that everyone's saying, thank God you're saying what we're all thinking.  I do think that this whole woke snowflake thing, it's a generational thing.  Very much younger people under... 30 under 25, but also it's a minority sport.
It's a minority sport, but also what's so wonderful is we live in this amazingly tolerant society, the most tolerant progressive society out there.
All of the evidence points to this.

And then you suddenly go, well, we've got to have something to get upset about, so they get upset about their oppression.  And also I think often it's a middle class thing.  It's about going, you know... I need to feel like I'm oppressed as well.  And let's just... We do what we often do in this country, which is, you know, lay all our troubles on the working man.  And I think the working man's tired of it.
And has risen up and spoken out.
Not that I am the working man.  But I have a job and I pay my bills.

He said quickly... What would your message be to those people who were angry and upset at what you had to say on Question Time?  And again, I thought a lot of the things you said on Question Time were things that certainly my feminist mother would agree was on the women's front and certainly the liberal values I was brought up with in terms of issues of ethnicity and colour and the like.  And now those considered to be far-right, dangerous, terribly unwoke views.  The people who were upset by that, who were angry at you, who were telling you you're an affront to womanhood and ethnic minorities and blah, blah, blah, and you don't understand how the world's really like... What would you like to say to them?  They're listening to you right now.  Trust me, they're listening to this right now.  What would you like to say to them?

I would like to say that I'm a human being.  I'm entitled to an opinion and I'm entitled to express it.  And I will respect yours if it's expressed back to me without hatred and venom.  And you want to have a conversation with me, I'm more than happy to have a conversation with you about anything.  That's how we get on in life.
Even the snowflakes?
Well, the snowflakes will just say you're a white, patriarchal, oppressive, tyrannical male and I can't deal with you because you're so awful and I'll just go, OK, have a nice day.

OK, well, despite the patriarchy, it's been a pleasure getting to meet you and meeting you in the studio.  Lawrence Fox, actor, musician and the latest hate figure, the one who's never there, someone I think most of us would agree is just speaking an awful lot of just common sense.  Since when did common sense become so uncommon and unfashionable?
That's a fascist thing to say and you should be very careful.  Common sense is a social construct.
I'm ashamed of myself, I really am.
